0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

2.name: New Terrorist Group Forms: Capitalist Werewolves

0.speaker: The Soldier
0.text: It seems that the old regime prepared sleeper cells of capitalist zealots, who waited for a time to strike.

1.speaker: The Soldier
1.text: They will try to slow down the transition to socialism.

2.speaker: The Soldier
2.text: We should try to keep the morale of the people high, so this scum have no support and no place to hide.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: I worry that pollinator populations are declining to dangerously low levels.

1.speaker: The Agronomist
1.text: Crop yields have been a bit lower than expected...this might be why.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: A collapse in pollinators will affect more than just crop yields.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: We need to improve biodiversity and lower extinction pressures to avoid catastrophe.

5.speaker: The Economist
5.text: Worldwide, honeybees yield roughly $200 billion in pollination services!

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: The fires have ravaged through dozens of communities who have lived peacefully in the woods.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: Many of the people effected are elderly and are not tech savy so they don't trust "apps". They think they are talking to a robot.

next.text: Team up with a mental health startup to provide teletherapy.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: People are suffering form PTSD from losing their homes, possessions, and pets. This is a mental health crisis!

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Economist
0.text: Have you heart of "craft" meat? I'm sure you have, cellular agriculture is making waves in the food tech sector.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: There's so much room in the city now that cars are gone!

1.speaker: The Agronomist
1.text: This is great news. This will take some load off of other parts of the food system.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: Urban gardening was something my neighborhood enjoyed doing...

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: ...but with all this extra space we began reclaiming plots for larger scale urban farming.

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: So far things are going well--we've been able to meet quite a bit of our own food needs.

5.speaker: The Agronomist
5.text: And these communities will be more resilient to food supply problems.

next.text: Regulate the price on flood insurance.

0.speaker: The Analyst
0.text: These floods are effecting millions of homeowners, the average damage is $30,000 per household and most homeowners can't afford flood insurance.

2.speaker: The Economist
2.text: We'll have to raise taxes.

3.speaker: The Doctor
3.text: Mold and mildew grows within 24 hours after flooding since it's drain water that floods homes, this is health crisis!

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

14.name: Collapse of the Greenland Ice Sheet

0.speaker: The Agronomist
0.text: Higher temperatures have altered soil microbial ecology, causing additional carbon to be released.

1.speaker: The Agronomist
1.text: This won't be good...

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

20.name: Island Nation Abandoned due to Rising Seas

22.name: Are We Protecting Too Much Land in Nature Preserves?

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is taking a lot of land out of use. We'll have much less land for food...are you sure this is a good idea?

23.name: A Global Dustbowl: Unsustainable Loss of Top Soil

0.speaker: The Farmer
0.text: I heard there were storms like this is my great grandfather's time. The soil just is blown away because we have ruined the land.

1.speaker: The Agronomist
1.text: As I see it, we have two options. Either expand our agricultural lands at the expense of wilderness or try other kinds of farming.

2.speaker: The Agronomist
2.text: Industrial agriculture gives us high yields, but it is akin to mining the soil. Pesticides, fertilizer, and irrigation each take their toll. About nearly half of global farmland is degraded and we're still losing 24b tonnes of top soil every year. Yields have peaked and will decline.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Holy Moly, we're running out of petroleum. It will be gone in twenty years, I reckon.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: Either cut down your energy-use or find another source of energy fast.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: There are reports of a major outbreak of a novel mosquito-borne disease.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: Warmer temperatures have been a boon for mosquito populations...

0.speaker: The Spacer
0.text: Reports of strange lights in the skies are coming in from all over the world.

1.speaker: The Spacer
1.text: What could it mean?

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Envoy
0.text: Revolts breaking out in {region}

0.speaker: The Spacer
0.text: We have all the technologies in place to send out ships to settle new planets.

1.speaker: The Spacer
1.text: We can't save Earth, at least not for everyone.

2.speaker: The Spacer
2.text: I urge you to focus establishing extraterrestrial human colonies...

3.speaker: The Spacer
3.text: ...so that at least some of our species will survive.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

43.name: Carnivore fanatics form terrorist group: The Leather Underground

0.speaker: The Posadist
0.text: We do not have a fantasist or idealist position with regard to flying saucers. As we accept that they exist, we want to use all means at hand, including those from outside of this planet.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Heatwaves are getting more intense

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: The "nightshift" has been said to increase health risks as well as potentially shorten lifespan!

2.speaker: The Economist
2.text: As we rely more heavily on air conditioners and fans, electricity bills will get higher.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: The increased demand for electricity, especially during peak periods, over-taxes the electrical grid, triggering brownouts and blackouts

4.speaker: Gossy
4.text: Energy companies have been preemptively shutting down power to avoid the possibility of sparking fires in the dry, windy conditions.  Pre-emptive blackouts could become a common occurrence.

next.text: Change the work hours of the day for outdoor workers.

5.speaker: The Doctor
5.text: We are seeing an overload of hospitalizations for people with outdoor professions - construction workers, miners, firefighters and agricultural workers are all heavily affected by increasing temperatures.

0.speaker: [GAME]
0.text: Your legacy as a planner was one that you feared most:

1.speaker: [GAME]
1.text: If only you could go back and try again...

2.speaker: [GAME]
2.text: ...leaving the world in a worse shape than you found it.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: More and more people are overwhelmed by dread. They fear a future of climatic disasters and mass extinction.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: This is causing serious mental health disorders, especially in the younger generations.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: You have to cool the planet and stop the Sixth Extinction so people can have hope.

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: The overuse of anti-biotics in animal husbandry and in poor countries that do not have effective healthcare systems has caused this problem.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: We estimate ten million people will die a year from what used to be preventable infections.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: It takes years of research to make new antibiotics, but now resistant strains emerge within a year.

image.attribution: "Staphylococcus aureus Bacteria" by NIAID is licensed under creative commons

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

53.name: Heatwave Kills Tens of Thousands of Elderly People

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: What a tragedy. A hundred thousand people perished last week in x, most of them elderly.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: We have to cool things down and fast, otherwise more people will die. These disasters make people lose hope that things will get better.

3.speaker: The Analyst
3.text: Some say that in 20 years we will see a significant shift in political ideology as the previous generations perish under the impact of climate change.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Go back again, now you have seen us, and your outward eyes have learned that in spite of all the infallible maxims of your day there is yet a time of rest in store for the world, when mastery has changed into fellowship. - William Morris

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: We've been engaged in a lot of big projects recently, which is good but bottlenecks are inevitable.

2.speaker: The Engineer
2.text: I suggest either running fewer competing projects or we could start deep-sea mining.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

64.name: Millions of Climate Refugees on the Move

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: What a disaster! All those people had to leave their homes and try to make a new life in the cooler, more stable parts of the world.

2.speaker: The Authoritarian
2.text: Don't be a fool. It's their fault they didn't adapt or prove resilient in these hard times. I say we keep them out.

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: We should help them, even if it will make things difficult for us here.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Methane will run out in twenty years at current usage.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: I suggest you find another source of energy posthaste.

0.speaker: The Envoy
0.text: Protests breaking out in {region}

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: A CO2 pipeline runs near to my town and last week it burst.

0.speaker: The Malthusian
0.text: Highly contagious? How interesting... It's almost as if nature itself is finally doing something about overpopulation.

69.name: Greenland Ice-Sheet Collapses, Causes Huge Tsunami

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Wide-ranging changes are needed to put us on a long-term path towards sustainability.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Here you can use your political capital to wrangle support for policies to implement worldwide.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Welcome to the Gosplant planning application. You can call me Gossy.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Got it?

5.speaker: Gossy
5.text: It's your job to guide us all safely through the next century.

6.speaker: Gossy
6.text: But you don't have complete authority to make decisions unilaterally.

7.speaker: Gossy
7.text: You'll need to spend political capital if you want something to happen.

8.speaker: Gossy
8.text: But if you run out of political capital, you will be recalled and your term will end.

10.speaker: Gossy
10.text: This planning application lets you make your plan.

12.speaker: Gossy
12.text: You can set research priorities, initiate large-scale projects, implement policies, or ban certain production processes.

13.speaker: Gossy
13.text: Following the recent revolution, you've been elected as the lead planner.

15.speaker: Gossy
15.text: And if the people are unhappy with your performance you will be removed from your position.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Alien
0.text: We have been observing your planet for some time now...

1.speaker: The Alien
1.text: We are encouraged by your efforts...

2.speaker: The Alien
2.text: they may not be enough, but any effort to right past wrongs should be nurtured.

3.speaker: The Alien
3.text: Good luck.

4.speaker: The Alien
4.text: ...and watched your struggles to right the wrongs of your species' past.

5.speaker: The Alien
5.text: So please accept this gift from us.

6.speaker: The Alien
6.text: In our travels we have not encountered any advanced life that is without a history of atrocity and ignorance.

7.speaker: The Alien
7.text: It will help dispel that warm shroud engulfing your planet.

8.speaker: The Alien
8.text: But not all reckon with that past.

9.speaker: The Alien
9.text: Or last long enough to try.

next.text: Halt funding research into moving industry to space.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: The space conservationists are getting media attention.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Agronomist
0.text: Amateur plant breeding has become a bit of trend lately!

1.speaker: The Agronomist
1.text: Citizens are trying to come up with their own crosses with better tolerances for more extreme climates.

2.speaker: The Agronomist
2.text: There have been a few notable successes! We're sharing these seeds with farmers around the world.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

97.name: Acid Rain Damages Infrastructure and Ecosystems

0.speaker: The Geoengineer
0.text: SRM triggered more acid rain than expected, but you can't make an omelette without breaking a few eggs, right?

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: What's worse, we will risk major accidents if this continues.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: The bridges and buildings are crumbling, you need to put more money into public infrastructure.

3.speaker: The Engineer
3.text: The sulphuric acid eats away at concrete, turning the calcium carbonate into gypsum. We'll have to rebuild many of our bridges and buildings decades years earlier than we expected.  People aren't happy about their cities seemingly melting away in front of their eyes.

5.speaker: The Ecologist
5.text: The loss of a bit of concrete is nothing compared to 'forest death'. Trees and lakes are dying from the increasing acidity of the soil and water.

0.speaker: The Geoengineer
0.text: We've got to do something about the rising temperature, there are so many options, what should we choose?

1.speaker: The Geoengineer
1.text: I recommend throwing all our options we have at the issue, one of them has got to work!

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

101.name: Epidemic X: Bad, but it could have been worse...

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: A new virus has emerged, either from a farm or the forest, we don't know yet for sure.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: As long as we have a large livestock industry and are putting pressure on ecosystems, these tragedies will keep happening.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: The mortality rate is 2%, which is bad but it could be much, much worse.

102.name: Fatal CO2 Leak from CCS Facility

0.speaker: The Envoy
0.text: Riots breaking out in {region}

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: We'll need help from various technologies and techniques to survive and flourish over the next century.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Here you can turn political capital into scientific capital and use that to set research priorities.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Not only new ones, but also the re-introduction and refinement of older ones too.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

image.attribution: NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (CC BY 2.0)

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: This happened once before in Europe during the 14th century, no one knows for sure why it started.

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: Perhaps the compulsive dancing allows some relief from stress and grinding poverty.

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: Maybe it's a dance craze, but my professional opinion is that people are too anxious. We've got to do something to make people's lives easier

0.speaker: The Malthusian
0.text: There are too many people in this world anyway.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: Floods are getting bad

111.name: Warming Leads to Declining Agricultural Yields

0.speaker: The Agronomist
0.text: While some crops are doing well with the heat and extra CO2 in the air, overall yields are down and will continue to go down for every degree of warming.

1.speaker: The Agronomist
1.text: Industrialized agriculture and vertical farming are the most resilient in the face of global heating, but the former ironically makes the problem worse by contributing to emissions.

2.speaker: The Agronomist
2.text: I recommend that you cool things off--fast--or we'll be seeing a lot of hungry people.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: The benefits of rewilding and regenerative agriculture are compounded, reducing the likelihood of more zoonotic disease.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Clearing of otherwise undisturbed land to make room for things like industrial farming opens up opportunities for the transmission of pathogens from animals to humans.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Well, the emergence of zoonotic diseases is closely related to ecological disturbance.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Wow, uranium stocks have been run down fast by the massive increase in reactors worldwide. At this rate, we'll run out of uranium in twenty years.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: If you want to keep the lights on, you better find alternative energy sources. If you want to stick with nuclear, we better do a crash course in researching fusion, fast-breeders, or thorium reactors.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: Wow, two dozen countries suffered from record heat-waves, some topping 50°C for weeks. People can only work at night when its moderately cooler.

0.speaker: The Authoritarian
0.text: A black market for meat was uncovered.

1.speaker: The Agronomist
1.text: It's not the worst thing--animal consumption is still way down.

2.speaker: The Authoritarian
2.text: I'm glad you see things my way.

next.text: I agree, we need to set an example.
These markets are small, there's no harm in letting them continue.

3.speaker: The Authoritarian
3.text: I say we clear them out.

4.speaker: The Authoritarian
4.text: We can't let this slide--what if it grows? It's undermining our legitimacy!

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Analyst
0.text: There are whispers on the Internet of a strange new group forming...

next.text: Let them be for now, we don't want to draw more attention to them.
Stamp them out, we can't risk it.

1.speaker: The Analyst
1.text: What should we do?

3.speaker: The Analyst
3.text: I'm a little worried about what will happen if they gain a larger following.

5.speaker: The Analyst
5.text: I can't find much on them, but many people who feel hopeless are drawn to their message.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This outbreak is much much worse than anything we've seen before...

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: The mortality rate could be as high as 50%. Hundreds of millions will likely perish.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: As long as we have animal husbandry and a biodiversity crisis, these epidemics can keep on happening.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: We have a wide array of processes to produce two critical resources: food and energy.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: They'll decide based on on-the-ground conditions and what production priority you set.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: A a planetary planner you can influence their decisions by banning or promoting certain processes, or by developing new ones through research.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: The exact mixes of processes is up to regional planners.

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: As you no doubt know, wildfires are growing in frequency and severity.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: There are several communities that live in high fire zones, when their homes are burn down they are displaced for long periods of time, some are never able to secure stable housing afterwards..

next.text: Team up with a mental health startup to provide aid.

4.speaker: The Doctor
4.text: Whole towns are suffering from PTSD, this is a mental health crisis!

6.speaker: The Citizen
6.text: Most of the people effected are elderly and not tech savy, they are suspicious of "apps" and think they are talking to a robot.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Economist
0.text: The mass electrification initiative is stretching existing copper production to its limit.

2.speaker: The Economist
2.text: Even with recycling there just isn't enough to meet our needs.

3.speaker: The Economist
3.text: We've developed new mines and expanded existing ones wherever residents consented.

next.text: We need this to happen--expand the mines!
We can't force more mines on people. Let the project take longer.

4.speaker: The Economist
4.text: But that hasn't been enough. What should we do?

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Your plans will benefit from having others on board.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: If a person trusts you enough they may be able to help you in unique ways.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Important figures within the world may join up with you depending on what decisions you make.

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: I didn't think it was possible, but it seems we will run out of coal in twenty years if we keep it up.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: I suggest you build up a new energy system quick time.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

134.name: SRM Fleet Shot Down--Brace for Termination Shock

0.speaker: The Soldier
0.text: This is the Commander of the Indian Armed Forces. We have shot down the international SRM Fleet because the 'stratoshield' has enervated the monsoons our country depends on.

3.speaker: The Geoengineer
3.text: We'll have to prepare for x degrees of heating in just a matter of months. This is bad, very bad.

5.speaker: The Soldier
5.text: We will use nuclear weapons to make sure that SRM will never happen again.

136.name: Torches and Pitchforks outside your window...

0.speaker: The Authoritarian
0.text: A mob of people have raided our building! They're looking for you.

next.text: Scum! This is the only way to save the planet!
I did what I thought was best.
I didn't know what I was doing!

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: We are tired of living under your tyrannical plans--they've brought us nothing but misery!

0.speaker: The Malthusian
0.text: As Garrett Hardin so eloquently once said, "The freedom to breed is intolerable."

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Wretched
0.text: You rich Northerners will not sacrifice half the world on your altar of greed and pseudo-ecology.

1.speaker: The Wretched
1.text: Ha, if you think there are too many people then let us help you get rid of the Malthusians!

2.speaker: The Analyst
2.text: Planner! Either you are with us or with the Wretched. Make your choice.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: Warmer waters means less oxygen, which is bad for most marine species. Many kinds of jellyfish, however, thrive in these conditions.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: It doesn't help that too much fishing means there are fewer predators and competitors for jellyfish.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Even if some people care little about the oceans, they'll be annoyed when their beach holiday is ruined.

image.attribution: Flensburg 2015-08 img13 jellyfish in bay water.jpg, creative commons

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Now we see what happens with your plan.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Of course, you can't plan for every possibility, and unexpected things will come up.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: As planner, people will come to you for guidance on decisions.

0.speaker: The Malthusian
0.text: I agree, the battle to feed all of humanity is over.

0.speaker: The Alien
0.text: We have been observing your planet for some time now...

1.speaker: The Alien
1.text: ...and watched your relentless war against all other life on the planet.

3.speaker: The Alien
3.text: We are obligated to defend life in all its forms!

151.name: Copper mining is poisoning the water supply

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: We've come to the end of your first planning cycle.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Improvements will foster confidence in your planning and gain you political capital.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: To manage your political capital you'll need to balance short-term improvements with your long-term plans.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: On the flip side, setbacks and worsening conditions will lose you political capital.

4.speaker: Gossy
4.text: At the end of each cycle you'll be presented a report summarizing changes.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Have you been to our Havana offices?

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: We have supercomputers to make a series of global plans simulating snapshots of the future: say, five detailed blueprints of the planet five years out, ten for the coming decade, and a couple dozen for the next quarter century.

2.speaker: Gossy
2.text: Oh it isn't just me. Thousands of people work there from all over the world.

3.speaker: Gossy
3.text: Havana has had the most experience with planning, decarbonization, and organic agriculture, so I guess it made sense to put the bureau there..

4.speaker: Gossy
4.text: Well, the parts of the world that have joined the Half-Earth bloc all provide data, technical expertise, and proposals to the central planning bureau in Cuba.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: Heatwaves are so regular and intense nowadays...

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: It's made life more bearable, although of course not everyone can work at night.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: ...most people can barely be outside during the day.

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: people sleep during the day, and do everything else at night.

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: My town has shifted everything to a night schedule--

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: It's happening...Almost all major pollinators are on the brink of extinction.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: This will just threaten broader ecosystems even more.

2.speaker: The Agronomist
2.text: We'll have to manually pollinate crops, which means yields will decline...

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: Pollinators were important to ecosystems beyond their role in agriculture too.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: With the vegan mandate livestock operations are stuck with billions of animals and nothing to do with them.

next.text: Create public sanctuaries where they can live out their final days.
We'll throw a series of feasts so they don't go to waste.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: What should we do with them?

4.speaker: The Ecologist
4.text: We can't release them into the wild because that would wreak havoc on ecosystems.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: My neighbors and I got rid of our lawns and encouraged native grasses to grow instead.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: Vole and shrew populations have rebounded, as have wildflowers like lupine.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: We've grown to appreciate how much we can do for our local environment, even as we try to change the world.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: These changes have brought a wealth of wildlife into our cities.

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: We rewilded the local golf course. I don't even miss the game as I got into birding instead.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: A major waste leakage....

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Doctor
0.text: The tests are in!

1.speaker: The Doctor
1.text: People seem happier now. Keep up the good work!

2.speaker: The Doctor
2.text: Declining fossil fuel combustion has meant a drastic drop in air pollution.

3.speaker: The Doctor
3.text: So many fewer respiratory illnesses and other complications, saving millions of lives a year.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Large-scale projects, like mass electrification or geoengineering schemes, will help provide the foundation for a better world.

1.speaker: Gossy
1.text: Here you can spend political capital to marshal resources towards building and sustaining these projects.

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: I’ve been living in the dorms for two years now, loved every second of it, but I’m not sure how long I’ll stay.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: Did you not see the last plan?

3.speaker: The Citizen
3.text: I think I’ll apply to work in Iowa when the time comes, unless these hands have gotten too old.

4.speaker: The Citizen
4.text: They’re letting most of Massachusetts rewild, since the soil’s not as good as out west. Right now some vegetables still make sense to grow at scale in New England, since it saves a bit on transport, at least until they finish the electric rail-lines out in the Midwest.

5.speaker: The Citizen
5.text: Once that project is done, though, this farm’s days are numbered.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: When's the government going to stop cramming this big projects down our throat?!

1.speaker: The Analyst
1.text: Perhaps try to make the people happier, so they will be more accepting of the future you are trying to build.

2.speaker: The Citizen
2.text: It's not that I'm against nuclear power, wind turbines, or whatever, I just don't want these projects in my backyard.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: Biodiversity has been plummeting...

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: I don't know if it will work, but it's worth a try.

2.speaker: The Ecologist
2.text: But there may be something we can try.

3.speaker: The Ecologist
3.text: ...in case the worst should come to pass.

4.speaker: The Ecologist
4.text: I'm afraid that most of Earth's species will be lost forever.

5.speaker: The Ecologist
5.text: It would have been better if we could have stopped extinctions from happening at all.

6.speaker: The Ecologist
6.text: I propose a project to collect and store DNA samples of earth's remaining biodiversity...

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: Ah, Esperanto! Cool idea!

0.speaker: The Citizen
0.text: There are many more birds than before because we have done so much to protect nature in recent years.

1.speaker: The Citizen
1.text: I like yellowhammers, one of Rosa Luxemburg's favourite birds. What's your 'spark bird'?

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: [GAME]
0.text: You step back from your planning console and let out a sigh...

1.speaker: [GAME]
1.text: Were they necessary, or did you just fumble your way through them?

2.speaker: [GAME]
2.text: You can't help but wonder how things could have gone differently.

3.speaker: [GAME]
3.text: Was this the only way?

4.speaker: [GAME]
4.text: So many unpopular and damaging decisions...

5.speaker: [GAME]
5.text: You managed to last all this time, but how has everyone else fared?

6.speaker: [GAME]
6.text: ..the weight of a century-long career shedding from your shoulders.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

181.name: Deadly Leak from CCS Storage Facility

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: CO2 is denser than air, so the deadly cloud stayed long enough at ground level to kill two thousand people and countless animals within minutes.

1.speaker: The Engineer
1.text: We try to store CO2 as safely as we can, but some accidents are inevitable. This will be bad for morale.

0.speaker: Gossy
0.text: This is placeholder for missing dialogue text

0.speaker: Gossy

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: The use of pesticides and fungicides is suspected to be a contributor to colony collapse.

1.speaker: The Ecologist
1.text: Colony collapse has the greatest impact in regions of 'industrial' or agricultural use of commercially bred bee colonies.

2.speaker: The Farmer
2.text: Bees are the main workers on the farms, without them we wouldn't be able pollinate and produce nearly as much yield.

3.speaker: The Farmer
3.text: Bees are the main workers on the farms, without them we wouldn't be able pollinate and produce nearly as much yield.

4.text: Bees are the main workers on the farms, without them we wouldn't be able pollinate and produce nearly as much yield.
